About me

Trained as theoretical chemist,

nurtured from computational biology,

developed to be a fan of enzyme.

• Postdoc in Chemistry, USC with Nobel laureate Arieh Warshel, 2020-now

• Postdoc in Chemistry, MIT, 2017-2020

• Visting Student at Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research, 2016

• PhD in Chemistry, Peking University, 2017

• BSc in Chemistry and Mathematics, Peking University, 2012

enzyme

Enzymes are remarkable biocatalysis that can tremendously accelerate chemical reactions. Our knowledge of enzyme mechanisms is still far from complete despite extensive studies through several generations of scientists. We recently introduced enzyme evolution into enzyme studies and developed the first-ever method to predict mutation effects on enzyme activity systematically. Currently, we are working on several related projects. Stay tuned!

chromatin folding and epigenetics

Why human has multiple cell types with the same DNA sequence? Because of the epigenome! We aim to understand the establishement of epigenetic information using data-driven approaches. Some of our predictions has been recently confirmed in experiment. The epigenome also affects chromatin folding, which plays critical roles in genome function. Our analysis of single-cell chromatin imaging data unraveled the phase separation mechanism caused by epigenome patterns. Importantly, we are able to quantify the energy landscape of chromatin folding using machine learning and statistical physics.

protein in solutions

Solutions are essential for life. Their properties at the molecular level can be best studied using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. We combined ab-initio MD simulations, pump-probe spectroscopy, and NMR to learn how TMAO interacts with urea in marine animals. We employed force-field MD simulations to explain the salt effects on protein structure and counterion effects on the ice nucleation on polyelectrolytes. These studies prompted us to propose a simple theory for the famous Hofmeister series. In another study, we also demonstrated how the electrolyte solution affects interleukin release through the GSDMD pore during inflammation.
